How can 90% of people lose their money on the stock market? Simple… they play monopoly or similar games with house rules, figure out that they are good at this and then try to emulate their success in real life… But, they do so in an uneducated way.. Most people buy a stock and wait for it to go up.. Most do not think of being short sellers, so they limit their game. But, they also buy and then get busy and then panic. If you are going to panic learn how to set stop-losses. This means that you can exit when it suits you and not when you happen to log in. Usually by then it is too late.. However, successful investors have a game plan. So they may buy Tesla at $350 next month, with a reasonable expectation that it would rise to $430 and then sell. They do not worry if it dips to $280… they expect it to go up because their models say so. But they listen to Musk’s tweets and if he says something bad, they accept that their model did not include him and cut their losses. Novices wait too long. Experts tend to buy the rumour and sell the news. Hence they would buy at $320 and sell 3 days before battery day.. When Musk tweeted that it was not great news… They sold. Also, novices will do crazy things like buy or margin when they do not have the spare capacity to cover the margin if the stock crashes… Bad. There are many, many ways to play this game. The trick is to get yourself a practice account and play the real game. Read up all the time and follow the companies you buy into…

Traders fail and lose all their money because they do not take their time with the required education and training to do this business. They do not go through all of the steps there are to be able to understand just what they are getting themselves into.  Trading is a vicious and brutal business to be in if you are not prepared for the brutality and volatility that go on in the live markets every day. The numbers are ugly for brand new traders. have a look at these books The Brutal Reality of Day Trading for Beginners, Day Trading Myths Revealed. It’s said that the average brand new trader loses an average of 25 thousand dollars in their first 3 months of trading live and 40 thousand in the first year, to me that’s just crazy! why not just do the education and training the right way from the first day and take you time. I always tell the traders I help out the market is always going to be there waiting to pay you. Brand new traders think they can learn a few chart patterns and then begin trading live against the best professional traders in the world, sorry newbie it doesn’t work like that. It takes at least a year to get it down pat and to be able to work from a strict rule based trading plan which you can follow in both good times and bad. It can take as long as 3–5 years to become consistently profitable. I know that’s not what you want to hear however it is the brutally raw truth. There is a certain progression that all brand new traders must go through and if you’re not willing to do it then I strongly urge you to look at some other type of business because only one thing happens from not doing this business right from the first day, you lose all your money, ALLLLLL OF IT! Check out my Quora blog Stock Trading Blogger (Stock Trading Blogger) and click on my profile to find out where else you can find me. I hope this helps Good luck with your trading and investing and remember: Trade smart…OR JUST DON’T TRADE! Stock Trading Blogger

Don’t take investing as gambling Let me repeat this in simple words- “INVESTING IS NOT GAMBLING!”. Do not buy any random stock and expect it to give you two times return in a month. 1. Get an education This is probably the most relevant do’s of stock market investing. If you really want to become a successful stock investor, start learning the market. It doesn’t mean that you should enroll in a college program/degree. Self-education is the best way to learn. There are tons of free information available on the internet which you access to learn the market. Moreover, if you want to get a head-start, you can also enroll in a few good online stock market investing courses. Let the learning begin. 2. Start small If you are just starting to learn how to swim, you won’t jump in 8 ft deep water, right? Similarly, when beginning to start investing in the stock market, start small. Invest the lowest possible amount and gradually increase your investments as you get more knowledge and confidence. 3. Get started early I cannot emphasize enough on the importance of getting started soon with your finances. Time is in your favor when you start investing early. Moreover, here you get enough time to recover even if you make some losses during the early time of your investment journey. 4. Research before investing One of the key reasons why people do not make money from stocks is that they do not put the initial efforts before investing in the share. Every investor needs to research the company before investing. Here you need to learn the company’s fundamentals, financial statements, ratios, management and more. If you do not want to regret later, research the company first before investing. 5. Only invest what is surplus: The stock market gives an immense opportunity to invest in your favorite companies and make money. However, there are always a few risks involved in the market, and no returns are guaranteed. Moreover, many times a bad (or bear market) may even last for years. Therefore, you should only invest the surplus money which does not affect your lifestyle even if you can’t get it out. 6. Have an investment goal It’s easier to plan your investments (and to monitor your progress) if you have an investment goal/plan. Your goal may be to build a corpus of Rs 10 Crores in the next ten years or to build a retirement fund. Having a goal will keep you motivated and on track. 7. Build a stock portfolio For making good consistent money from the stock market, just having two or three stocks is not enough. You need to build a winning stock portfolio of 8–12 stocks which can give you reliable returns. Although it’s very less likely that you can find all the fantastic stocks to invest at once. However, year-after-year you can keep adding/removing stocks to build a strong portfolio that can help you reach your goals. 8. Average out: It’s challenging to time the market and almost impossible to buy the stock at the exact bottom and sell them at the highest point. If you’ve done it, you might be lucky. 9. Diversify “Do not put all your eggs in one basket!”. The risk involved while investing in just one stock is way higher compared to a portfolio of ten stocks. Even if one or two of your stock starts performing poorly in the later scenario, it may not affect the entire portfolio too much. Your stock portfolio should be sufficiently diversified. 10. Invest for the long-term It’s a common fact that all the veterans of the stock market who made an incredible fortune from stocks are long term investors. But why do long-term investing helps to build wealth? Because of the power of compounding, the eighth wonder of the world. If you want to build massive wealth from the market, invest for the long-term. 11. Hold the winners, cut the losers Cut you losing stocks if they under perform for a long time and hold your winning stocks longer to allow them to offer even better returns. This is the golden mantra of investing that you should strictly follow. Moreover, keeping your winners and cutting losers will also help in building your dream portfolio. 12. Invest consistently Most people get excited and enter the stock market when the market is doing well, and the indexes are touching new highs. However, if you only invest in a bull market and exit when the market is down i.e. when stocks are selling at discount, you will never find fantastic opportunities to pick cheap stocks. Do not invest in the market just for a year. If you want to make good money from stocks, invest consistently and periodically increase your investment amount. 13. Have Patience Most stocks take at least 1–2 years to give good returns to the investors. Moreover, the performances get better when you give more time. Have patience while investing in the share market and do not sell your stocks too soon for short term gratification. 14. Don’t have unrealistic expectations: Yes, many lucky guys in the market have made 400–500% return on their single investment. However, the truth is that these kinds of news get quickly circulated (and inflated). Have realistic expectations while investing in stocks. A return between 12–18% in a year is considered good in the market. Moreover, when you compound this return over multiple years, you will get way higher returns compared to 3.5% interest on your savings account. Further, do not assume that you can get the same profits as others, who might be investing in stocks from many past years and may have acquired an amazing skill set. You can also get similar returns, but only after enough knowledge and practice. 15. Don’t over trade When you are trading frequently, you are repeatedly paying for the brokerage and other charges. Don’t buy/sell the stocks too often. Take confident decisions and make transactions only when necessary. 16.Don’t follow the herd Your colleague purchased a stock and made 67% returns from it within a year. Now, he’s boasting about it, and many of your office-mates are buying that stock. What would you do next? Should you buy the stock? Wrong! No investor can get significant success from the market by following the herd. Do your own research, rather than following the crowd. 17. Don’t take unnecessary risks Investing all your money in a hot stock/industry to get a little higher return is never a wise move. Safeguarding your money is equally important than getting high returns. You should never take unnecessary risks while investing in stocks and your ‘risk-reward’ should always be balanced. 18. Don’t make emotional decisions The human mind is very complex, and there are many factors both internal and external that can affect the choices we make. While investing in the stock market, do not take emotional decisions. No matter how much you like a company, if it is not profitable and doesn’t have a bright future potential, it may not be the right investment decision. Do not get emotional while making your

Common mistakes done by beginners, according to me are Not having goals, both short term and long term , and randomly investingInvesting on an impulse, on “tips” and not doing a thorough researchGetting swayed by emotions or getting carried away by events around us.Not monitoring the portfolio regularlyPutting all eggs in one basket..not spreading the risk.I have mentioned certain simple steps to investing for new to market customers in the link below..hope you find it usefulR Kalyanaraman's post in New to Market Investors

I think 100% of the traders lose some money at some time in the market. I don’t trade. I invest. I also lose some money in a few cases. I am ready for that. If 90% of the traders lose money continuously, consistently, they would be out of business sooner or later. So, obviously that is not correct. The same trader keeps losing in some and gains in some trades. He may lose in 80 to 90 percent of his trades but lose small amounts. He may make a big gain in the balance trades. The trader may lose on some days of the week but may make up for the losses on other days.

More than 90% lose. The winners would barely cross 5%. Even the winners can say with certainty that they have retained all their income and developed only at the time of their death. Because one or two bad trades with outsized position can wipe out several years of income. This bloated ego comes, when we feel we can do no wrong, after seeing a series of successful trades. Till then your position sizing would be under control. Continuous success is capable of giving a high, which can lead to a bloated ego, at which time caution is first thrown to the winds, and complacency sets in.

The stats I’ve seen indicate that more than 90% of day traders lose, more like 95% to 98% depending on the time frame measured. The advertising for day trading must be very compelling for some audience. People would never consider running against Usain Bolt, but somehow think they’ll outperform experts as novice traders. Truly bizarre. You should also read what the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC is the US regulator for stocks) has to say in this link: Day Trading: Your Dollars at Risk Take particular note of the line:“Be prepared to suffer severe financial losses”

Market goes up or comes down, every buyer has a seller vice a versa. So ideally 50% should be successful n rest failure but here failure percentage goes 95 why? There are no of reasons for you can Google the list. 95% are those who here comes for easy and quick money, only profit is in there mind they refuse To accept loss is a part of the game. When loss comes they stick to the loosing position in hope fortune will turn their way. Unfortunately this way huge dent cause to capital size. Now they want to recover the loss desperately and market reward patience traders. Trading is phycological game here one should forget profit fantasy be realistic. Focus should be on how to save capital. As long as you are in the game you will figure out profitability some day. Learn as much as you can , formulate strategy calmly, know how to exit loosing bet. Those who learned to manage the risk, profit will follow eventually.

By ‘trading’ I’m interpreting your answer to mean active trading in financial markets. There are two reasons most traders fail, one you can manage and one you can’t. bid/ask spread. think of this like the 0 on a roulette wheel. The more you play, the more it statistically will erode your long term profitability. Very large hedge funds / asset managers such as Pimco can minimise this by virtue of their size- they get mid pricing as investment bank flow desks welcome the volume.Taking too much risk. Most people take far too much. To give an idea, most amateur traders will take risk that blows you out at a 1 or maybe 2 standard deviation price move, trying to return multiples on their investment. Pro traders will be much more risk adverse, trying to make maybe 5-10% over a whole year.in short, it comes down to having incredible discipline and maths to be a good trader. Even then, you have to beat the spread.

Having knowledge on Technical Analysis is not enough to be profitable in trading. Profit mainly comes with risk management and discipline. Traders should accept that trade sometime don’t work, in fact trades fail more often than they sustain. Since there is no method of foretelling which trade will work, traders have to be consistent and disciplined in the market to be profitable. Traders should always think about risk before reward and be at least two times more focused on risk per trade than reward. Not able to master the risk and reward in trading is probably one of the main reasons why so many traders are destined to fail. It is one of the ways to get an edge in the market place. Trading is a marathon. Wonderful opportunity comes to those who trade with patience and thoughtful plan with effective use of their available capital. Great trades sometime come with small losses. Keeping losses in check is a key to successful trading. In trading, it’s important to have a plan and more important is having discipline in executing that plan. Pay attention to what is actually happening rather than what you expect to happen.

response.answer_text: Very Design(of stock market) is that 90–95% of stock market(esp. retail) participants have to loose money. Technically and statistically, the system people follow might not have a positive edge in it. Psychologically, 3 factors contribute: Fear (of missing out and of Losing), Greed and Hope. Yes, if you play intraday, FNO or short term trading. If you hold stocks for say 3–5 yrs or more, you will not loss. Also if you start SIP in mutual fund and stay invested for minimum 5–7 yrs, then you will not loss money. If you borrow money and play in margin, then you will loss money. Put your extra money which is not required for at least 3–5 yrs. No one can become wealthy obernight. So have,patience and invest regularly and relax.

response.answer_text: In a zero-sum game, there are always losers. If the fat cats always win, the majority of others must lose.  OK, the stock market is not a classical zero-sum game, but very close to it.
